nodes.text: A likelihood-based vector autoregressive error correction framework provides a unified, testable parametric approach to model cointegration among nonstationary economic time series and to conduct inference on long-run relations and adjustment dynamics

Definition: A p-dimensional process x_t is integrated of order one, I(1), if its differences are stationary linear processes with nonzero sum of MA coefficients, and x_t is cointegrated if there exists nonzero beta such that beta' x_t is stationary

Granger Representation Theorem (applied to VAR error correction form): under the I(1) condition the solution of the VAR error correction model decomposes into r stationary cointegration relations beta' x_t and p-r common stochastic trends C sum_{i=1}^t epsilon_i with explicit moving average representation C and C*

Three parametric formulations of cointegration: (a) regression residual approach (Engle-Granger), (b) autoregressive error correction VAR formulation Delta x_t = alpha beta' x_{t-1} + short-run terms, (c) unobserved components formulation with stochastic trends linked to alpha and beta

Model analyzed: VAR error correction model Delta x_t = alpha(beta' x_{t-1} + Upsilon D_t) + sum_{i=1}^{k-1} Gamma_i Delta x_{t-i} + Phi d_t + epsilon_t, with alpha and beta p x r matrices, deterministic terms parametrized to control trending behavior

Economic examples illustrating cointegration: (a) Purchasing Power Parity as stationary linear combination e_t - p_us_t + p_au_t, (b) present value relation implies cointegration between stock price and dividends with cointegrating vector (1,-theta,0,...,0)

I(1) condition for the VAR: characteristic polynomial Psi(z) has unit root at z=1 and the rank condition |alpha_perp Gamma beta_perp| != 0 ensures only order one pole so xt is cointegrated I(1) and avoids I(2) or higher integration

Likelihood estimation and testing: Gaussian maximum likelihood estimation of model (2) reduces to reduced rank regression (RRR) of Delta x_t on lagged levels and deterministic terms, producing eigenvalue problem and ML estimates alpha, beta, Gamma and Omega

Rank test and test statistic: likelihood ratio test for cointegration rank r versus p is -T sum_{i=r+1}^p log(1 - lambda_hat_i) where lambda_hat_i are eigenvalues from RRR; maximized likelihood relates to product of (1 - lambda_i)

Granger representation implications for deterministic terms: deterministic dt cumulates via C Phi sum dt producing trends in levels, while D_t multipliers proportional to alpha do not cumulate because C alpha Upsilon = 0; choice of deterministic terms affects asymptotic distributions

Asymptotic distributions: (a) rank test has nonstandard Dickey-Fuller type limit distributions depending on p-r and deterministic specification (Brownian motion functionals), (b) estimator of beta is mixed Gaussian with conditional Gaussian limit given common trends, while estimators of alpha and short-run parameters are asymptotically Gaussian and asymptotically independent of beta

Inference procedures: given mixed Gaussian limit for beta, Wald and likelihood ratio tests on cointegration coefficients are asymptotically chi-square under appropriate normalization and identification restrictions; rank selection uses simulated critical values or small-sample corrections/bootstrap

Extensions and applications: rational expectations impose testable restrictions on cointegration and short-run parameters in VAR; model extends to I(2) processes with parametrizations yielding cointegration between levels and differences and to nonlinear, seasonal, explosive or fractional integration cases

Limitations and open problems: (a) small sample bias and need for small-sample corrections and bootstrap methods, (b) underdeveloped statistical theory and methods for nonlinear cointegration, (c) need for economic theory to incorporate empirical findings on nonstationarity and cointegration
